When writing tests, one verifies expected behavior by writing assertions.
A=
ssertions are method calls, (e.g. assertTrue, assertEquals, and many others=

explained in http://www.junit.org/apidocs/org/junit/Assert.html) that test=

against values produced by the test.  They throw AssertionFailedError when=
 a
particular condition is not met.

The exception you got shows that the f=
ollowing assertion failed:

  assertEquals(
    "Message variable contains =
message",
    instance.getContextInstance().getVariable("message"),
    "Go=
ing to the first state!-auction"
  );

There are three arguments to this as=
sertEquals assertion. First, the string
is a message that is printed when t=
he assertion fails. The messages are
usually used to help with debugging by=
 describing what an assertion does in
a human-readable way.  The second arg=
ument is the expected value and the
third is the actual value. In your exam=
ple, the arguments are backward. It
is most common for the expected side to=
 be a literal (in this case a String)
and the actual side to be the result =
of the computation that you want to
test.

  assertEquals(
    "Message var=
iable contains message",
    "Going to the first state!-auction",
    insta=
nce.getContextInstance().getVariable("message")
  );

Back to your error. W=
hen assertEqual fails, it shows the string values of
the expected and actua=
l sides to again aid in debugging. Therefore, the
exception you got is tell=
ing you that the getVariable method returned null
when it should have inste=
ad returned the string "Going to the first
state!-auction". The test has fa=
iled and you need to start debugging to find
out why.

Brett
